Now with the wood pigeons, they are a much

so you want to get a nice head shot if you

269.text:
I am going to try and go through and hit the

the one at the back then, he held his head

So I have just done the replay on that pigeon

It all depends on the pellet drop here. So

377.text:
So you can see on that pellet there, we have

383.text:

389.text:
is had a pellet in there that was like that

394.text:
So that is probably what we are getting. That
is not necessarily the fault of the pellet

398.text:

storage of your pellets. If you have dropped

404.text:
the tin or dropped pellets on the floor and
pick them up and put them back in that is

407.text:
what you can get and so you can get deformities
in there. So it really does pay to be very

412.text:
careful with your pellets and make sure they
don’t get deformed and knocked about too

Every now and again we hear a boom from the

head shot. It's so important to practice so

463.text:
So obviously you can see this pigeon was shot

the entry wound there. He was poking his head

anything with the air rifle, obviously you

479.text:
either want to be taking a head shot, a neck

485.text:
preferably if you can take the spine out as
well, they drop on the spot, or tend to drop

489.text:
on the spot. So you have only got a very small
margin for error though. When you think that

496.text:
the main part which is going to kill the pigeon
is just behind the eye, so you have got a

500.text:
very small target there. Probably about the
size of a 5 pence piece if you are looking

505.text:
at him side on. So taking away the feathers
and everything else it doesn’t give you

510.text:
much of a target. So you need to make sure
your air rifle is spot on and you have practiced

515.text:
shooting from lots of different positions
so you are used to shooting from a standing

519.text: position, a leaning position and what ever

521.text:
else. So you ensure your pellet ends up to
where you want to hit it.

As the afternoon marches on the number of

717.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

727.text:
Thank you David. Next a really big gun. Tim
Pilbeam is testing the Daystate Wolverine.

736.text:
The Daystate Wolverine .303 has got people
talking - Some say 'it's awesome'. Others

742.text:
point out that, in order to own this work
of Dr Frankenstein the UK you need to have

747.text:
a fire arms certificate - and if you have
an FAC why on earth would you bother about

751.text:
air when you can have powder? Well today we
want to find out if this beast is worth howling

757.text:
about. Instead of putting it in the hands
of an air gunner, we're giving it to a rifle

761.text:
reviewer who hasn't been air gunning since
he was in shorts.

765.text:
The last time I shot an air rifle, I was 15
years old and then as soon as I got my hands

770.text:
on a .22 Rimfire I saw the light and that
was it. That was the very last time and that

774.text:
was 35 years ago and now I am faced with a
30 calibre air rifle which is brilliant. So

780.text: I am looking forward to this.

781.text:
Tim certainly likes the look of the Daystate,
but before we see if it does the job, what

787.text:
about applications. To put it bluntly - what's
the point of it?

791.text:
Quite a few plus points for the .303. Beyond
150 yards these are very, very safe. The pellets

797.text:
just fizzle out and very, very low ricochet
so very inherently safe, soft, malleable pellets.

805.text:
Secondly the ammunition is a bit cheaper than
the .22 Rimfire. Apparently there are some

812.text:
police forces who are steering people towards
an FAC air rifle, because they feel it is

817.text: safer than a .22 or a .17 HMR.

821.text:
The biggest worry for Tim is animal welfare.
Not the fuzzy kind peddled by the antis. Tim

826.text:
wants to see his animals drop to the shot
and he knows his rifles will do exactly that.

831.text:
If you are going to kill an animal, make sure
you kill it with plenty of power. But air

835.text:
rifles have moved on an awful lot over the
last 35 years. So we need to look at these

840.text:
types of air rifles again and see what they
are capable of.

843.text:
So Tim is willing to give the Wolverine benefit
of the doubt... However - he wants to do a

848.text:
quick couple of comparison tests between his
.22, a .17HMR and this .303

857.text:
We have got 5 bits of wood here. They about
15mm wide. Let’s see how deep the bullets

862.text:
travel into the wood. So the .17 has gone
through 60mm plus of wood. The .22 has gone

872.text:
through 45 say 50mm. And the .303 Wolverine
has gone nearly through 30mm of wood. What

883.text:
that tells me is that the Wolverine .303 has
a lot better knock down power than the actual

890.text:
.22. The .22 with a rabbit tends to go straight
through a rabbit whereas a Wolverine I suspect

896.text:
will actually stop in the rabbit itself which
is very safe and I suspect it will knock the

900.text: rabbit over a lot better than the .22 Rimfire.

903.text:
Next, let's look at accuracy. Here are some
targets he prepared earlier..

907.text:
Comparing the Rimfires to the .22 Wolverine.
This is a .17HMR 17 grain bullet at 50 yards

913.text:
we achieved about .6 of an inch grouping.
There were very windy conditions today so

919.text:
not the best conditions to check the grouping.
The .22 Rimfire 40 grain bullet, we achieved

925.text:
about 1inch grouping at 50 yards which is
quite respectable. The .303 Wolverine in fact

931.text:
we have actually got 10 shots here - very,
very windy and whilst we got 2 slight fliers,

937.text:
most of the shot went into the middle there.
So I think as the day went on the actual Wolverine

943.text:
improved quite a bit. So I am very happy with
the accuracy of the .303.

946.text:
So far, the Wolverine seems to pack a punch
and it is pretty accurate - delivering all

952.text:
that energy where it counts - but what about
the real thing? Well, Tim has a couple of

956.text:
myxamotosis sufferers that we can use for
the last test.

961.text: First up it's the .22 - then the .303.

968.text:
This is the rabbit shot with the .22 Rimfire.
We have got an entrance wound there which

973.text:
has actually come straight through. You can
just see that which is standard for a .22

979.text:
at about 50 yards. With the impact the rabbit
moved quite a bit so I was quite surprised

986.text:
on that. But that is fairly normal penetration
exit wound for a rabbit. On the .303 once

995.text:
again we have got an entrance wound there,
but it has actually come out the other side.

1004.text:
What is interesting is that the rabbit didn’t
actually move. The pellet went straight through.

1010.text:
I would have thought with the knock down power
of the .303 this rabbit perhaps fall straight

1017.text:
over the bag. But is stayed still and the
bullet went straight through it. Interesting

1022.text:
observation, nothing scientific about this,
just interesting to see how a rabbit reacts

1028.text:
to a heavier bullet. In this situation it
went straight through it. The next thing we

need to do is go out into the field at night
time and knock a few bunnies over and see

All eyes are on the Wolverine tonight - and

with Tim driving and lamping. Rabbit number
one is hit hard and drops - a good start but

1062.text:
Just shot a rabbit about 35 yards away with

1070.text:
through the front shoulder. At the moment

So what we do is get the knife out and have

if there is actually anything in there. The

In fact we have had a closer inspection and

1093.text:
So on this occasion the pellet went straight

1107.text:

Fortunately as ever foxes tend to, if they

1136.text:

1157.text:
that stops the animal straight away. It is

Here we got a rabbit not very far away. I

1187.text:
the pellet went straight through the neck,

1197.text:
go. So the pellet has passed through the neck

1206.text:
Which is slightly surprising because you have
got some hard neck bone tissue there and also

1215.text:
at the bottom of the jaw here - I can feel
it now. That is all very hard bone and the

1220.text:
pellet has gone straight through and out the
otherside. I would have though an air rifle

1226.text:

1237.text:
We haven't had the volume of rabbits we had

1240.text:
got a feel for this rifle...so the big question

1247.text:
I suppose I have got to look at it from a

1254.text:
It performed, we shot 3 or 4 rabbits and every
single time the pellet went straight through

1260.text:
the animal and actually on 2 occasions we
didn’t actually get a complete kill straight

1266.text:
away, which is slightly concerning. If has
been a .22 Rimfire I think on both those occasions

1272.text:
I would expect the rabbit to be dead. With

1278.text:
of the explosive nature of the air rifle.
It is a beautifully built air rifle. Beautiful

1282.text:
bit of wood here, but after a night out shooting,
I think I will stick with my .22 Rimfire and

1287.text:
my .17 HMR. But it has been a very, very interesting

1294.text:
It's not for Tim, but it is an exciting addition

1299.text:
feared by enemies of the British army right

556, and thank goodness there are British

the sometimes staid old world of airguns.
For more information about the wolverine and

From airguns to shotguns and getting people

The Novice Schools Challenge aims to introduce

1326.text:
a gun before. The hope is that some will continue

If we have 10 that take it up that is a result

1335.text: You would be happy with that.

10 more people shooting, 10 more customers

1344.text:
the shooting industry going. 10 more guns
out there. It will keep it going. So if that

piece about catching chub. What he’s talking
about is touch ledgering, where you feel the

1584.text:
weight bumping along the bottom of the river
bed. "You can bump and feel, and also use

1589.text:
your left hand," he says "It’s so sensitive,
you can feel the bite". Fnarr fnarr.

1594.text:
Now we go 6,000 miles to California where
‘Jeremy Salmon Fishing 2’ is a cute film,

1600.text:
mainly to 1980s computer game music, showing
an angler catching a chum salmon that has

1605.text:
run up from the Pacific. And then showing
his increasingly desperate attempts to let

1609.text: it go. He succeeds in the end.

1611.text:
Staying in America, it’s not quite our experience
of deerstalking but here’s a keen hunter

1615.text:
, Casey Shoopman, editor and videographer
for ManagementAdvantage, who is planning what

1620.text:
corn to leave on his farm in Illinois in order
to attract deer. He is talking about crops

1626.text:
and vegetation we barely grow and know in
Europe but the film has some useful tips about

1630.text:
what he reckons deer want for cover and for
food.

1633.text:
Now we’re back in the UK again and looking
at rodents. Top of the list is this test of

1637.text:
thermal imaging equipment by LordLardOfFrams
which includes plenty of rabbit shooting.

1643.text:
Next we have rat hunting and CountryPursuitsTV
is getting baity - that is he is showing off

1647.text:
the secrets off his best baits for ratting.
You get seven minutes of Malcolm being a kind

1653.text:
of vermin version of Delia Smith but eventually
he takes the stuff out to try it out on the

1658.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch
them. If you have a YouTube film you would

1662.text:
like us to pop in to the weekly top eight,
send it in via YouTube, or email me the link

1670.text:
Well If you like shooting you will love the
Shooting Show. It is appearing on the screen

1674.text:
just up there in the sky. Byron Pace is going
out after Mountain reedbuck in Africa and

1683.text:
Both at home and abroad, episode seventeen
of The Shooting Show takes in the best shooting

1687.text:
sports the planet has to offer. Byron is in
South Africa, where he finds himself heading

1693.text:
up dirt tracks into the mountains for a mountain
reedbuck cull with a couple of old friends.

1698.text:
They are on the trail of rams and ewes. Back
in Britain, Pete Carr spots a roebuck living

1704.text:
dangerously close to a busy road. There is
the threat of a road traffic accident, so

1709.text:
the pressure is on to go out stalking and
grass the buck quickly. It’s a textbook

1713.text:
stalking and the gralloch. The Shooting Show
has also got the latest on British medals

1716.text:
at the Paralympics and big bags shot during
this year’s grouse season.

1721.text:
Now if you are watching this on Youtube, please
don’t hesitate to hit the subscribe button

1725.text:
that is somewhere around the outside of the
screen there, or click on our shows page which

1729.text:
should be appearing about there www.youtube.com/shows/fieldsportsbritain
that is where you get just this show and not

1737.text:
everything else we do. Or go to our website
www.fieldsportschannel.tv you can click to

1742.text:
like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter
scroll down to the bottom, pop your email

1746.text:
address into the ConstantContact box and we
will constantly contact you. This has been
